noun.description: Soft fibers from fabrics such as wool or cotton which accumulate in small light clumps.
examples: he brushed his sleeve to remove the fluff

noun.description: Entertainment or writing perceived as trivial or superficial.
examples: the movie is a piece of typical Hollywood fluff

noun.description: A mistake made in speaking or playing music, or by an actor in delivering lines.

verb.description: Make (something) appear fuller and softer by shaking or brushing it.
Fail to perform or accomplish (something) successfully or well (used especially in a sporting or acting context)
examples: the extra fluffed his only line

origin: Late 18th century: probably a dialect alteration of 16th-century flue down, nap, fluff, apparently from Flemish vluwe.
